content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
What if the difference between a 5% interest rate and an 8% rate on a $25,000 car loan cost you $2,400 extra over five years?

Your credit profile determines which rate you get ‚Äî and understanding how lenders evaluate you is the first step to getting the best terms.

terms.definition: A three-digit number (300‚Äì850) calculated from your credit history that lenders use to assess risk ‚Äî higher scores qualify for lower interest rates and better loan terms
terms.example: A 750 credit score may qualify you for a 5.5% auto loan rate while a 620 score for the same loan could mean 10.5% ‚Äî a difference of thousands of dollars over the loan term

terms.definition: Your total monthly debt payments divided by your gross monthly income ‚Äî lenders use this to assess your capacity to take on additional debt; most lenders prefer DTI below 43%
terms.example: If you earn $4,000/month and pay $1,200 in debt payments, your DTI is 30% ‚Äî generally acceptable; $1,800 in payments would be 45% DTI and may trigger loan denial

terms.definition: An asset pledged as security for a loan ‚Äî if you default, the lender can seize the collateral to recover their loss; secured loans typically offer lower rates than unsecured loans
terms.example: Your car is collateral on an auto loan ‚Äî if you stop making payments, the lender repossesses the vehicle. A mortgage uses the home itself as collateral

terms.definition: The true yearly cost of borrowing money, expressed as a percentage ‚Äî includes interest rate plus fees, making it a more complete measure of loan cost than the stated interest rate alone
terms.example: A personal loan advertised at 7% interest with $200 in origination fees may have a 7.8% APR ‚Äî the APR reveals the true cost including all charges

layoutData.title: How Lenders Evaluate Every Application
paragraphs: Lenders assess every loan application using the Five C's framework ‚Äî a systematic evaluation of your creditworthiness that determines both whether you're approved and what rate you receive.
bulletPoints: Character: Your track record of repaying debts ‚Äî reflected in your credit score, payment history, and length of credit history. The most important factor: do you pay what you owe?
Capacity: Your ability to repay ‚Äî measured by your debt-to-income ratio (DTI). Lenders verify income, calculate existing obligations, and determine if you can afford additional payments
Capital: Assets and savings you own beyond income ‚Äî down payment, emergency fund, investment accounts. More capital = lower risk; 20% down on a home eliminates PMI
Collateral: Assets securing the loan if you default ‚Äî a car or home as collateral reduces lender risk and typically earns you a lower rate than unsecured personal loans
Conditions: The loan's purpose and current economic environment ‚Äî lenders consider why you're borrowing, economic conditions in {{STATE_NAME}}, and interest rate environment

keyPoint.text: üí° You can influence all Five C's before applying: build credit history (Character), pay down debts (Capacity), save more (Capital), offer collateral (Collateral), and apply during favorable conditions.

leftPanel.title: What Borrowers Pay in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Interest rates vary by loan type, credit score, and current economic conditions in {{STATE_NAME}}. Understanding typical rate ranges helps you evaluate offers and know when you're getting a good deal.
bulletPoints: Auto Loans ‚Äî Rates typically 5‚Äì15%+ depending on credit score; new cars average lower rates than used
Personal Loans ‚Äî Rates range from 7% (excellent credit) to 35%+ (poor credit); shop multiple lenders
Mortgages ‚Äî 30-year fixed rates fluctuate with Fed policy; credit score impacts rate by up to 1.5%
Student Loans ‚Äî Federal loans have fixed rates set by Congress; private loans vary by credit score
Credit Cards ‚Äî Average APR exceeds 20%; minimum payment traps keep borrowers in debt for years in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.headerTitle: How Interest Rates Affect Your Payments

leftPanel.title: Small Rate Differences, Big Dollar Impact
paragraphs: Even a 1‚Äì2% difference in interest rate adds up to thousands of dollars over a loan's life. Building credit before applying can save you more than a year of careful saving.
bulletPoints: Auto Loan Example ‚Äî $25,000 over 5 years: at 5% = $472/mo ($28,307 total); at 8% = $507/mo ($30,412 total) ‚Äî $2,105 difference from credit score alone
Mortgage Example ‚Äî $300,000 over 30 years: at 6% = $1,799/mo; at 7.5% = $2,098/mo ‚Äî $107,280 difference over loan life
Personal Loan ‚Äî $10,000 over 3 years: at 8% = $313/mo; at 24% = $392/mo ‚Äî $2,880 difference
Shopping Around ‚Äî Getting one better quote in {{STATE_NAME}} often saves as much as cutting expenses for months

layoutData.title: Gather These Before You Apply
paragraphs: Lenders require documentation to verify your income, employment, assets, and identity. Having these ready before applying speeds approval and prevents delays.
bulletPoints: Income Verification: Last two pay stubs showing year-to-date earnings; W-2s from the past two years; if self-employed, two years of tax returns and profit/loss statements
Employment Verification: Employer contact information; length of employment; letter of offer if you recently started a new job in {{STATE_NAME}}
Asset Documentation: Last two months of bank statements; investment and retirement account statements; proof of down payment source (lenders verify funds aren't borrowed)
Identity and Residency: Government-issued photo ID; Social Security number; proof of {{STATE_NAME}} residency (utility bill, lease, or prior tax return)

keyPoint.text: üí° Missing documentation is the #1 cause of loan application delays. Create a folder with all documents before submitting your first application ‚Äî organized borrowers close faster and project the 'Character' lenders are looking for.

scenario.name: Darius ‚Äî First Car Loan in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Darius, 22, needs a car for his new job in {{STATE_NAME}}. He has a 680 credit score, $2,000 saved for a down payment, and earns $38,000/year. He visits the dealership and is offered 9.9% APR. Not knowing better, he almost signs.

Instead, Darius checks with his credit union before signing. His credit union offers 6.4% APR ‚Äî and he negotiates the car price separately from financing. On a $18,000 loan over 5 years, the lower rate saves him $1,540 and he keeps control of the deal.

content.headerTitle: Credit Score Components ‚Äî What Moves the Needle

leftPanel.title: The Five Factors That Build Your Score
paragraphs: FICO scores ‚Äî used by 90% of top lenders ‚Äî are calculated from five weighted factors. Knowing the weights tells you exactly where to focus your credit-building efforts.
bulletPoints: Payment History (35%) ‚Äî Single biggest factor; one 30-day late payment can drop your score 50‚Äì100 points; on-time payments are the foundation of good credit
Amounts Owed / Credit Utilization (30%) ‚Äî Keep balances below 30% of credit limits; ideally below 10%; maxed cards are major score killers
Length of Credit History (15%) ‚Äî Older accounts help; don't close old cards even if you don't use them
New Credit (10%) ‚Äî Hard inquiries from applications temporarily lower score; avoid multiple applications at once
Credit Mix (10%) ‚Äî Having both revolving (cards) and installment (loans) credit helps; don't open unnecessary accounts just for mix

stats.label: Weight of payment history ‚Äî the single most impactful factor in your credit score
Weight of credit utilization ‚Äî keep balances below 30% of limits for best scores
Credit score threshold for best available rates on most loan products in {{STATE_NAME}}

layoutData.title: Six Moves That Improve Your Loan Profile
paragraphs: You can meaningfully improve your loan application strength in 6‚Äì12 months with deliberate action. These strategies address multiple Five C's simultaneously.
bulletPoints: Pay On Time, Every Time: Set up autopay for minimums; payment history is 35% of your score ‚Äî one missed payment can cost you dearly
Pay Down Balances: Reducing credit card balances to below 30% utilization can raise scores 20‚Äì40 points within 1‚Äì2 billing cycles
Become an Authorized User: Being added to a family member's old, well-managed account adds their positive history to your credit file
Save a Larger Down Payment: More capital reduces lender risk; 20% down on a home eliminates PMI and often earns a better rate in {{STATE_NAME}}
Dispute Errors: Check all three credit bureaus (Equifax, Experian, TransUnion) for errors; 1 in 5 reports contain mistakes that hurt scores
Reduce DTI Before Applying: Pay off or pay down existing debts to improve your capacity ratio before submitting new loan applications

keyPoint.text: üí° Request your free credit reports at AnnualCreditReport.com ‚Äî the only federally mandated free source. Review all three bureau reports for errors before any major loan application.

layoutData.title: Errors That Cost Borrowers in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Many borrowers make avoidable mistakes that result in higher rates, loan denial, or damaged credit. Knowing these pitfalls helps you sidestep them before they become costly.
bulletPoints: Accepting the First Offer: Dealerships and banks profit from higher rates ‚Äî always compare at least 3 lenders before accepting any loan in {{STATE_NAME}}; credit unions are often best
Applying for Multiple Loans Simultaneously: Multiple hard inquiries from different lender types hurt your score; rate-shop within a 45-day window for it to count as one inquiry
Closing Old Credit Accounts: Closing a card reduces available credit and potentially credit history length ‚Äî both hurt your score even if the card is paid off
Borrowing Your Down Payment: Lenders verify down payment sources; borrowed down payments typically disqualify applications or require disclosure ‚Äî save genuine capital
Ignoring Pre-Approval: Shopping for a car or home without pre-approval leaves you negotiating from weakness; pre-approval sets your budget and strengthens your position

keyPoint.text: üí° Rate shopping is smart ‚Äî not harmful. Multiple auto or mortgage inquiries within a 45-day window count as a single hard inquiry on your credit score. Shop aggressively for the best rate.

takeaways.title: Five C's Determine Your Rate

takeaways.title: Small Rate Differences = Big Dollars

takeaways.title: Shop Multiple Lenders
takeaways.description: Always get at least 3 quotes ‚Äî credit unions, banks, and online lenders ‚Äî before accepting any loan offer; competition saves real money

takeaways.title: Build Credit Before You Need It
